title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: Ithen passed on for a stroll. The post office is situatedat the bottom of Market Street, and next to it is theDouglas Hotel. At this place I found the landlordor proprietor, a congenial and kind man, and soon anarrangement was struck for my letters to be addressedto his hotel.

title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence
snippet: Between 1828 and 1830 Scott lived at No. 6 Shandwick Place — now Maitland Street, a continuation  of Princes Street. In February, 1831, while superintending the making of his will, he was the guest of his bookseller, Robert Cadell, in Athol Crescent, and the last night he spent in Edinburgh was at the Douglas Hotel, 34 and 35 St. Andrew Square, now the office of the Scottish Union and Insurance Company; and on the morning of the iith of July, 1832, he was carried unconscious from this house and from Edinburgh, to die at Abbotsford  two months later. 6*

title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence
snippet: As Lockhart writes,"The sensation produced by this scene was, in newspaper phrase, ' unprecedented.' title: A Question of Penmanship. Stories
author: Walford, Lucy Bethia
snippet: " So are you, I suppose ? We are allin our ' braws,' you see," laughing ; " bonnets, yousee ; parasols, you see : there 's Mysie, now, has neverhad a bonnet on her bit of a head before, let alone apink parasol! Upon my word, I feel quite abashedto be escorting three such grand ladies along thestreets. But you will come with us, will you not ?The breakfast is at the Douglas Hotel, as usual, Iunderstand."

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: The populace had known that his Gracewas dining with the Commissioner, and were waiting for his exit. When accordingly he presentedhimself at the door, he was saluted with hisses,and a storm of voices crying out " Cheap whisky ! "Lord Belhaven wished the Duke to take a seat inhis carriage, but he declined; and, accompanied bythe Marquis of Lothian and some of his friends,walked quietly along to the Douglas Hotel, the

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: Here we take in and leave passengers; then we coast along theshore of Bute, passing Mountstuart, the seat of the Marquis of Bute,and, rounding Garroch Head, steer straight for Arran in the distance. We first come to Corrie, where there are a few cottages, and landsome passengers by a ferry-boat which comes alongside; afterwards weround the point into Brodick Bay, and land at the pier at Invercloy,opposite the Douglas Hotel, where we put up at two o'clock p.m. onSaturday afternoon. The scenery on the island is wild and grand, withGoatfell towering high above everything else.
